WHAT IS VIETNAMESE ÁO DÀI? 👗

Literally translated to “long shirt,” áo dài is considered the national garment of Vietnam. It is a form of traditional Vietnamese formalwear — consisting of a long tunic (split at the sides) worn over a pair of wide-legged silk trousers 👖

Áo dài was born in the 18th century by the Nguyễn lords in Phú Xuân — but the modern + more form-fitting version that we know now was popularized in the 1930s, heavily influenced by French haute couture. While typically depicted on women, áo dài can be worn by all genders!

We love wearing our áo dài to temple to celebrate the New Year — but they can generally be worn to all sorts of special occasions, like weddings or holiday celebrations 🏮 Happy Year of the Dragon 🐲
